posts.name: donald
posts.cooked: For the new wcp radio the documentation says it’s capable of passive poe, to other devices but I can’t find the actual amount of power a port can put out, anyone know or know where to find it?

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
I brought this up a few weeks ago on the new radio thread. It has yet to be answered and is not in the docs.

[FRC Blog] New Radios at 2024 FIRST Championship General Forum

link_counts.title: [FRC Blog] New Radios at 2024 FIRST Championship

posts.name: Kevin Emery
posts.cooked:
The documentation for this is available from the Vivid Hosting website: https://frc-radio.vivid-hosting.net/getting-started/passive-power-over-ethernet-poe-for-downstream-devices

By enabling the PoE output using the switches on the bottom of the radio, the corresponding ethernet port will be energized with the same voltage level provided by either the PoE input on the RIO port and/or the 12V Weidmuller input.

So if you’re powering your radio with 12V power, the POE ports will send 12V. If you’re powering your radio with 18V power (like off the RPM ), the POE ports will send 18V.

link_counts.title: Passive Power over Ethernet (PoE) for Downstream Devices | English | FIRST FRC Radio

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: That’s just voltage, not power tho (for DC    P=V*I )

posts.name: Kevin Emery
posts.cooked: My apologies! I missed that you were specifically looking for Watts, not voltage.

posts.name: Kiet Chau
posts.cooked:
username2:

For the new wcp radio the documentation says it’s capable of passive poe, to other devices but I can’t find the actual amount of power a port can put out, anyone know or know where to find it?

The Vivid-Hosting VH-109 radio demonstrated a continuous 15W per AUX port during our lab testing.

(Anecdotal testing warning!) Through testing throughout the past two seasons, they were able to run two Limelight 3’s with LEDs on constantly.

Just be sure to use appropriate gauge wiring on both the source of the radio and the sinking devices.
